required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

brief_summary.textblock: This study is designed as a prospective, non-randomized, observational clinical study. The study will collect clinical and rrEEG (Ceribell EEG) data when monitoring subjects for delirium subtypes. EEG and clinical data will be collected for the development of future software algorithms to assess the presence and severity of delirium.

primary_outcome.measure: Perform Confusion Assessment Method for the ICU (CAM-ICU) assessment
primary_outcome.time_frame: 2 times per day, for a maximum of six (6) days
primary_outcome.description: Research coordinator will perform and collect CAM-ICU assessment data on study subjects

primary_outcome.time_frame: 6-8 hours per day, for a maximum of six (6) days
primary_outcome.description: Record and collect EEG brain waves on study subjects using Ceribell Rapid Response EEG to assess multiple time-frequency EEG features to differentiate between delirium positive and delirium negative patients.

intervention.description: EEG test and delirium assessments will be performed on subjects experiencing delirium in the ICU.

study_pop.textblock: Subjects who experience at least one delirious episode during their ICU stay

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria: All must be present
- Age is 18 years or older
- Clinical suspicion of delirium or subject at risk for delirium
- Admitted to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU)
- Expected ICU stay is greater than one (1) day
- Subject must be fluent in English
Exclusion Criteria: All must be absent
- Age is younger than 18 years
- Subjects with a primary neurological or neurosurgical condition such as stroke, epilepsy, brain tumor, or witnessed seizures, Parkinson's disease, traumatic brain injury, craniectomy, known severe dementia, or CNS infection
- Active CNS substance abuse, intoxication, or withdrawal
- Unarousable or unresponsive subjects with RASS < -3
- Subject is blind, deaf, or unable to speak or understand English

Delirium detection in older acute medical inpatients: a multicentre prospective comparative diagnostic test accuracy study of the 4AT and the confusion assessment method. BMC Med. 2019 Jul 24;17(1):138. doi: 10.1186/s12916-019-1367-9.

Maclullich AM, Anand A, Davis DH, Jackson T, Barugh AJ, Hall RJ, Ferguson KJ, Meagher DJ, Cunningham C. New horizons in the pathogenesis, assessment and management of delirium. Age Ageing. 2013 Nov;42(6):667-74. doi: 10.1093/ageing/aft148. Epub 2013 Sep 25. Review.

Tieges Z, Evans JJ, Neufeld KJ, MacLullich AMJ. The neuropsychology of delirium: advancing the science of delirium assessment. Int J Geriatr Psychiatry. 2018 Nov;33(11):1501-1511. doi: 10.1002/gps.4711. Epub 2017 Apr 9. Review.

Ely EW, Margolin R, Francis J, May L, Truman B, Dittus R, Speroff T, Gautam S, Bernard GR, Inouye SK. Evaluation of delirium in critically ill patients: validation of the Confusion Assessment Method for the Intensive Care Unit (CAM-ICU). Crit Care Med. 2001 Jul;29(7):1370-9.
Kaplan PW. The EEG in metabolic encephalopathy and coma. J Clin Neurophysiol. 2004 Sep-Oct;21(5):307-18. Review.

patient_data.ipd_description: Site investigators will have access to the participant EEG data via Ceribell EEG portal. In addition, site investigators will have access to delirium assessments conducted for study purposes.

study_doc.doc_comment: This website is password protected and the de-identified individual participant data is only available to participating research sites.
